text: - Hi, I'm Josh from AWS.
- I'm Shihas Vamanjoor from Prudential
and This is My Architecture.
(upbeat music)

- So Shihas, Prudential is a
large financial institution

and I imagine that with
that territory comes lots
of challenges around data, amounts of data

and different types of data
and how to deal with that.

Can you tell us a little bit
more about those challenges

and have you dealt with
them in this architecture?

- Prudential, like any other
modern enterprise needs

to create its data products
faster and cheaper,

and this architecture
delivers on the promise

of increased product creation
velocity at lower cost.

- [Josh] So I'm looking at
here at this user coming
into this marketplace.
Can you tell us about that flow
and why you chose this model?
- The primary purpose of the marketplace
is to create a browser-based experience
where the user can discover,
understand,
and access data.

This is the purpose of the
marketplace application.

It simplifies the entire
data community's experience
with the data estate.

And this is done through
a series of automations
that move data across the different zones
that you're seeing on the screen.
- [Josh] So it comes in here.

I see some kind of manifest
or document file here
and then it's coming in through DataSync.
Can you tell us about that flow

and specifically why
you chose DataSync here
or if there are other services?
- [Shihas] Sure.

The manifest contains
instructions for the kind

of data the user would like to
move across the data estate.

For example, the data could
exist in file systems,
databases, APIs, streams, any number

of different source
systems in the enterprise.
DataSync is an example of an AWS service

that we use to bring
data from file systems.
There are other services

that we currently do not
represent on this rise,

including Glue, which is connected
to JDBC sources, Kinesis,

which is connected to
streaming sources, DMS,

which is connected to
databases, sources and so on.

But the manifest-driven
experience abstracts a user

from the nature of the
source and the transport
and shipping involved in knowing data
across this particular estate.
- It sounds like it's really adaptable

and flexible to a bunch
of different data types,

which is what we were
talking about earlier

with all those different data
types and UC enterprises.

So we have S3 and Redshift
in the next phase here
in the standardization.
How does Glue DataBrew factor
into that standardization story
and why do you have S3 and Redshift?

- [Shihas] So the purpose
of this application
is to support multipurpose usage of data.
S3 represents a lake pattern of usage,

which is connected to data
science and machine learning.

Redshift is connected to a
house pattern of architecture,
which is usually connected
to business intelligence use cases.

And Glue DataBrew is
our transformation tool,

which we use to dynamically
create the automatic workflows

to move data from the landing
zone to a standard zone

that represents the source
in a time series manner.

This layer is also extensible
with other technologies such

as vector databases, as
well as graph databases.
- So looking at all these services,

you talked about the data lakes
and all the standardization
and refinement steps,
there's usually a lot of data engineers,
human activity involved in this process,
but you're looking to automate.

How much of this is
currently automated today?

- [Shihas] You point
to an important concept

that addresses both velocity
as well as lower cost.

This portion of moving
data from the source
to the landing zone, which is step one

and to the standardized
zone, which is step two,
is fully automated.
So no human being writes code
anywhere at Prudential to do this.
The subject of refinement of data,
which is where business rules are written,

this is where human engineers
come into this picture.

Now they spend most of
their time in this space.

Historically, they would have
spent a significant portion

of that 80% in moving the
data across this estate.

- Yeah, so now they can
focus on what matters

and add value here in
the refinement stage.

I wanna move to lake formation
in this governance step here.

Lake formation I imagine is
playing an important role
in governing the rest of this workflow.

Can you tell me more
about how you're using it?
- Sure.

Now, one of the three things
that the marketplace allows
you to do is discover, find, and access.

The access is where lake
formation comes into this picture.
Now, throughout this journey,
what we've described is a shipping model
and an organizational model for data
that brings data to a usable form.
Now comes access to this data,

which is a security and
a governance question.
Lake formation is a service that we use

to centrally secure
access to S3 and Redshift.

Now, the marketplace
similarly delivers access

through the manifest, which
is an instruction, a request

for access, which then goes
through approval workflows.

That is the purpose of using
AWS lake formation here
to centrally govern all access privileges
across this estate.

- Yeah, what I like here is
that the user can specify

what they want to achieve
and not necessarily

how it's going to be
achieved under the hood.
You can automate that away

and you can have the lake
formation manage the governance,
and you can have these automation steps

hinder the standardization.
- Yes.

AWS services work very well
under this abstraction layer

of a marketplace application
in order to orchestrate

these flows minus the user
having to know about them.
That is correct.

- [Josh] And then lastly,
we have this SageMaker
and Athena consumer section here.
Can you tell me a little bit about that?
- This layer represent consumption models,

which is both traditional as
well as advanced analytics.
Athena represents a SQL interface.
SageMaker is a machine learning interface.
You could introduce any third party tools
as well into this picture.

- So this is a very extensible
and flexible architecture

and I thank you so much
for sharing with us today.
Thanks for having me.
(upbeat music)
